item.title: #es @ 1499940113765310464
item.description:

item.title: #en @ 1499870339207155712
item.description: Entering data for my meta and found a dissertation from the 1970s that has *completely open data* - every datapoint, every calculation and every item is in the appendix! Easier with tiny samples, I know, but I'm still in awe - it's making my life so much easier >40 years later!

item.title: #en @ 1499813120059002890
item.description: Back in the DAY (=2007, y'all) I interned at the Epigraphische Datenbank Heidelberg (EDH) which I still adore and is the easiest for me to search with. They now have Latin and some Greek: https://t.co/QBLfZE1qLv It is all linked open data under a CC BY-SA 4.0 license, too!

item.title: #en @ 1499811988301664258
item.description: In addition, https://t.co/yhI1VJmqsc (usually known for papyri) is doing amazing things with linked open data and epigraphy. Their search functionality allows you to search across corpora and media (as the plural of medium) on stone, papyrus, ostrakon, etc https://t.co/JhWJatnZWh

item.title: #en @ 1499708421771255811
item.description:
Tomorrow is #OpenDataDay - we're proud of the work we do with repair data from around the world.
Open data is *so* important because it means anybody can access and analyse the data. And reuse it.
Most of the data in the world is owned by companies, or government bureaucracies
